senses.definition: the quality or fact of being very fat, in a way that is not healthy

examples.en: Obesity can increase the risk of heart disease.

senses.definition: to do what you are told or expected to do

examples.en: to obey a command/an order/rules/the law
He was arrested when he failed to obey a police instruction to stop.
He has turned into an efficient soldier, blindly obeying orders (= without questioning them).
He had always obeyed his parents without question.
I tried to run but my legs just wouldn't obey me.
‘Sit down!’ Meekly, she obeyed.

senses.definition: a thing that can be seen and touched, but is not alive

examples.en: everyday objects such as cups and saucers
inanimate objects (= things that are not alive)
a physical/material object (= that you can see and touch)
The scanner detected a metal object.
We now know that solid objects are largely made up of empty space.
art objects from the ancient world

senses.cf: object of desire, study, attention, etc.
senses.definition: a person or thing that somebody desires, studies, pays attention to, etc.

examples.en: He felt he was nothing more to her than an object of desire.
Her objects of study are all paintings.
an object of affection/ridicule/worship

senses.definition: an aim or a purpose

examples.en: Her sole object in life is to become a travel writer.
The object is to educate people about road safety.
The object of the game is to score points by combining cards.
If you're late, you'll defeat the whole object of the exercise.

examples.cf: with the object of doing something
examples.en: He put together an army with the object of taking back the lost territory.

senses.definition: a noun, noun phrase or pronoun that refers to a person or thing that is affected by the action of the verb (called the direct object), or that the action is done to or for (called the indirect object)
money is not something that needs to be considered, because there is plenty of it available

examples.en: She travels around the world as if money is no object.

senses.definition: to say that you disagree with or oppose something

examples.en: If nobody objects, we'll postpone the meeting till next week.
Members of the council strongly objected to plans to sell off the land.
Many local people object to the building of the new airport.
I really object to being charged for parking.
Who could object to people having fun?

senses.definition: to give something as a reason for opposing something

examples.en: He objected that the police had arrested him without sufficient evidence.
‘But that's not fair!’ she objected.

senses.definition: a reason why you do not like or are opposed to something; a statement about this

examples.en: I'd like to come too, if you have no objection.
They raised no objections at the time.
He did not know how to voice his objections.
The main objection to the plan was that it would cost too much.
There was widespread objection to the proposals.
I have no objection to him coming to stay.
I have no objection to staying here.
The proposal will go ahead despite strong objections from the public.
He dismissed the objection that the plan was too expensive.

senses.definition: something that you are trying to achieve

examples.en: the primary/principal/key objective
The main objective of this meeting is to give more information on our plans.
How does the project fit with our strategic objectives?
the government's policy objectives
to achieve/meet/accomplish your objectives
to set/state/define your objectives
You must set realistic aims and objectives for yourself.
What are the organization's goals and objectives?

senses.definition: the lens in a telescope or microscope that is nearest to the object being looked at
not influenced by personal feelings or opinions; considering only facts

examples.en: an objective assessment of the situation
objective truth/facts/reality
objective criteria/measures/measurements
He doesn't even pretend to be impartial and objective.
It's hard to remain completely objective.

senses.definition: existing outside the mind; based on facts that can be proved

examples.en: objective reality

senses.definition: the objective case is the one which is used for the object of a sentence
the state of being forced to do something because it is your duty, or because of a law, etc.

examples.en: You are under no obligation to buy anything.
She did not feel under any obligation to tell him the truth.
I don't want people coming to see me out of a sense of obligation.
We will send you an estimate for the work without obligation (= you do not have to accept it).

senses.definition: something which you must do because you have promised, because of a law, etc.

examples.en: legal/professional/financial obligations
They reminded him of his contractual obligations.
The country has promised to comply with its international obligations.
We have a moral obligation to protect the environment.
I have an obligation under law to protect their confidentiality.
I felt that there was a moral obligation on me to tell the story.
We want to fulfil our obligation to farmers and see they get a fair price.
The company did not have enough money to meet its obligations.
We have an obligation to our consumers.

senses.definition: to force somebody to do something, by law, because it is a duty, etc.

examples.en: Parents are obliged by law to send their children to school.
I felt obliged to ask them to dinner.
He suffered a serious injury that obliged him to give up work.
Libel plaintiffs are virtually obliged to go into the witness box.

senses.definition: to help somebody by doing what they ask or what you know they want

examples.en: Call me if you need any help—I'd be happy to oblige.
Would you oblige me with some information?
Oblige me by keeping your suspicions to yourself.
The fans were looking for another goal and Kane duly obliged.

senses.definition: the act of watching somebody/something carefully for a period of time, especially to learn something

examples.en: Most information was collected by direct observation of the animals' behaviour.
results based on scientific observations
We managed to escape observation (= we were not seen).
The suspect is being kept under observation (= watched closely by the police).
She has outstanding powers of observation (= the ability to notice things around her).
an observation post/tower (= a place from where somebody, especially an enemy, can be watched)
an observation deck (= a room or platform at the top of a tall building which provides views of the surrounding area)
his close observations of animal life in its natural setting

senses.definition: a comment, especially based on something you have seen, heard or read

examples.en: May I make a personal observation?
He began by making a few general observations about the report.
She has some interesting observations on possible future developments.
her witty observations on life

senses.definition: to see or notice somebody/something

examples.en: Have you observed any changes lately?
All the characters in the novel are closely observed (= seem like people in real life).
I want you to observe all the details.
The patterns observed in our study may represent a general rule.
The police observed a man enter the bank.
They observed him entering the bank.
She observed that all the chairs were already occupied.
He was observed to follow her closely.

senses.definition: to watch somebody/something carefully, especially to learn more about them

examples.en: He observes keenly, but says little.
I felt he was observing everything I did.
The patients were observed over a period of several months.
an observed decrease in rainfall in the area
The program provided an opportunity to observe the effects of treatment.
The cells were observed under a microscope.
The patient should be observed for signs of an allergic reaction.
They observed how the parts of the machine fitted together.

senses.definition: to make a remark

examples.en: She observed that it was getting late.

senses.definition: to obey rules, laws, etc.

examples.en: Will the rebels observe the ceasefire?
The crowd observed a minute's silence (= were silent for one minute) in memory of those who had died.

senses.definition: to celebrate festivals, birthdays, etc.

examples.en: Religious festivals were always observed.

senses.definition: a person who watches somebody/something

examples.en: According to observers, the plane exploded shortly after take-off.
To the casual observer (= somebody who does not pay much attention), the system appears confusing.
Most art forms require a contribution from the observer.

senses.definition: a person who attends a meeting, lesson, etc. to listen and watch but not to take part

examples.en: A team of British officials were sent as observers to the conference.

senses.definition: a person who watches and studies particular events, situations, etc. and is therefore considered to be an expert on them

examples.en: a royal observer

senses.definition: to completely fill your mind so that you cannot think of anything else, in a way that is not reasonable or normal

examples.en: He's obsessed by computers.
She's completely obsessed with him.
The need to produce the most exciting newspaper story obsesses most journalists.

senses.definition: to be always talking or worrying about a particular thing, especially when this annoys other people

examples.en: I think you should try to stop obsessing about food.

senses.definition: the state in which a person’s mind is completely filled with thoughts of one particular thing or person in a way that is not reasonable or normal

examples.en: Her fear of flying is bordering on obsession.
There's a national obsession with celebrity in England.
The media's obsession with the young prince continues.

senses.definition: a person or thing that somebody thinks about too much

examples.en: Fitness has become an obsession with him.

senses.definition: a situation, an event, etc. that makes it difficult for you to do or achieve something

examples.en: So far, we have managed to overcome all the obstacles that have been placed in our path.
A lack of qualifications can be a major obstacle to finding a job.
The MP claims that there is now no obstacle to him standing at the next general election.
The huge distances involved have proved an obstacle to communication between villages.

senses.definition: an object that is in your way and that makes it difficult for you to move forward

examples.en: The area was full of streams and bogs and other natural obstacles.
He managed with difficulty to negotiate the obstacles strewn across the floor.

senses.definition: a fence, etc. for a horse to jump over

examples.en: This huge open ditch forms the biggest obstacle on the course.

senses.definition: to get something, especially by making an effort

examples.en: to obtain information/data/results
I've been trying to obtain permission to publish this material.
I finally managed to obtain a copy of the report.
Further details can be obtained by writing to the above address.
To obtain the overall score, add up the totals in each column.

senses.definition: to exist

examples.en: These conditions no longer obtain.

senses.definition: easy to see or understand

examples.en: I know you don't like her but try not to make it so obvious.
He agreed with obvious pleasure.
It soon became obvious that the machine did not work.
It's painfully obvious that the budget was low for this movie.
It's obvious a change is needed.
It was obvious to everyone that the child had been badly treated.
The lessons seem fairly obvious to anyone who doesn't work in the Administration.
It's obvious from what she said that something is wrong.
For obvious reasons, I'd prefer not to give my name.
The reasons for this decision were not immediately obvious.
It is blindingly obvious that there is not enough money to finance this public spending programme.
It was far from obvious how they were going to get off the island.

senses.definition: that most people would think of or agree to

examples.en: She was the obvious choice for the job.
There's no obvious solution to the problem.
This seemed the most obvious thing to do.
an obvious example/answer/question

senses.definition: not interesting, new or showing imagination; unnecessary because it is clear to everyone

examples.en: The ending was pretty obvious.
I may be stating the obvious but without more money the project cannot survive.

senses.definition: used when giving information that you expect other people to know already or agree with

examples.en: Obviously, we don't want to spend too much money.
Diet and exercise are obviously important.
I wanted to do well, obviously, but I wasn't nervous because I don't see exams as the be all and end all.
She responded 'Oh well, obviously I disagree with him'.
This massive storm obviously had a huge impact on air travellers.

senses.definition: used to say that a particular situation or fact is easy to see or understand

examples.en: He was obviously upset.
They're obviously not coming.
‘I didn't realise it was a formal occasion.’ ‘Obviously!’ (= I can see by the way you are dressed)
This story is so obviously false that Matthew doesn't bother to refute it.

senses.definition: a particular time when something happens

examples.en: on this/that occasion
I've met him on several occasions.
They have been seen together on two separate occasions.
On one occasion, she called me in the middle of the night.
Only on rare occasions do I go out socially.
I can remember very few occasions when he had to cancel because of ill health.
He used the occasion to announce further tax cuts.
I have stated on numerous occasions what options are open.
Harry has mentioned this on many previous occasions.

senses.definition: a special event, ceremony or celebration

examples.en: a great/memorable/happy/momentous occasion
Turn every meal into a special occasion.
They marked the occasion (= celebrated it) with an open-air concert.
Their wedding turned out to be quite an occasion.
We expect you to dress for the occasion.
He was presented with the watch on the occasion of his retirement.
Every good wish to them on the occasion of their 40th anniversary.

senses.definition: a suitable time for something

examples.en: It should have been an occasion for rejoicing, but she could not feel any real joy.
These workshops provide an occasion for talking about art.
This is not a time for specifics, but an occasion for vision.
Festivals were occasions for great celebration.
I’ll speak to him about it if the occasion arises (= if I get a chance).

senses.definition: a reason or cause

examples.en: I've had no occasion to visit him recently.
She doesn’t have much occasion to speak French in her new job.
Her death was the occasion of mass riots.
Art here is an occasion for education and entertainment.
I'm willing to go to court over this if the occasion arises (= if it becomes necessary).

senses.definition: sometimes but not often

examples.en: He has been known on occasion to lose his temper.

senses.definition: a feeling or understanding that an event is important or special

examples.en: Candles on the table gave the evening a sense of occasion.

senses.definition: to cause something

examples.en: The flight delay was occasioned by the need for a further security check.
The injury was believed to have occasioned his death.
The decision occasioned us much anxiety.

senses.definition: happening or done sometimes but not often

examples.en: He works for us on an occasional basis.
The occasional sweet treat won't do you any harm.
He spent five years in Paris, with occasional visits to Italy.
an occasional drinker (= a person who drinks alcohol, but not often)

senses.definition: sometimes but not often

examples.en: We occasionally meet for a drink after work.
This type of allergy can very occasionally be fatal.
Only occasionally was there any doubt that they would succeed.
Johnston is an intelligent, occasionally brilliant writer.
Cook on a medium heat for 20 minutes, stirring occasionally.

senses.definition: a job or profession

examples.en: Please state your name, age and occupation below.

senses.definition: the way in which you spend your time, especially when you are not working

examples.en: Her main occupation seems to be shopping.

senses.definition: the act of moving into a country, town, etc. and taking control of it using military force; the period of time during which a country, town, etc. is controlled in this way

examples.en: the Roman occupation of Britain
The zones under occupation contained major industrial areas.
occupation forces

senses.definition: the act of living in or using a building, room, piece of land, etc.

examples.en: The offices will be ready for occupation in June.
The following applies only to tenants in occupation after January 1 this year.
The level of owner occupation (= people owning their homes) has increased rapidly in the last 30 years.

senses.definition: to fill or use a space, an area or an amount of time

examples.en: The bed seemed to occupy most of the room.
As the company grew, it continued to occupy more space.
Administrative work occupies half of my time.
How do you occupy your time?
Their time is fully occupied with their rigorous training regime.

senses.definition: to live or work in a room, house or building

examples.en: He occupies an office on the 12th floor.

senses.definition: to enter a place in a large group and take control of it, especially by military force

examples.en: The capital has been occupied by the rebel army.
Protesting students occupied the TV station.

senses.definition: to fill your time or keep you busy doing something

examples.en: a game that will occupy the kids for hours
Problems at work continued to occupy his mind for some time.
She occupied herself with routine office tasks.
She occupied herself doing routine office tasks.

senses.definition: to have an official job or position

examples.en: The president occupies the position for four years.
jobs that have traditionally been occupied by men

senses.definition: to happen

examples.en: When exactly did the incident occur?
Something unexpected occurred.
Three major events occurred in my life that year.
These chemical changes occur naturally.
In most years more deaths occur in winter.

senses.definition: to exist or be found somewhere

examples.en: Sugar occurs naturally in fruit.
naturally occurring chemicals in the brain
Lemurs occur in the wild only in Madagascar.
Infected plants frequently occur in patches.
Calluses typically occur on the bottom of the feet and heel.

senses.definition: something that happens or exists

examples.en: a common/everyday/frequent/regular occurrence
Vandalism used to be a rare occurrence here.
The program counts the number of occurrences of any word within the text.

senses.definition: the fact of something happening or existing

examples.en: the recent occurrence of skin cancer in younger patients

senses.definition: the mass of salt water that covers most of the earth’s surface

examples.en: The ship was dredged from the depths of the ocean.
People were swimming in the ocean despite the hurricane warning.
The plane hit the ocean several miles offshore.
Our beach house is just a couple of miles from the ocean.
ships large enough to sail the open ocean
an ocean liner
a species of fish that lives on the ocean floor
El Nino is a warm ocean current that appears off the coast of Peru during the winter.
Ocean levels are rising.

senses.definition: one of the five large areas that the ocean is divided into

examples.en: the Antarctic/Arctic/Atlantic/Indian/Pacific Ocean
They travelled across oceans in search of a new life.

variants.text: (North American English a drop in the bucket)
variants.html: (North American English a drop in the bucket)

senses.definition: an amount of something that is too small or unimportant to make any real difference to a situation

examples.en: The amount of money raised was a drop in the ocean compared to what we needed.

variants.html: (also oceans of something)

senses.definition: a large amount of something
the 10th month of the year, between September and November

examples.en: She was born in October.
The meeting is on the fifth of October/October the fifth.
The meeting is on October fifth.
We went to Japan last October.
I arrived at the end of October.
last October's election
the October issue of the magazine

senses.definition: strange or unusual

examples.en: They're very odd people.
There's something odd about that man.
That painting looks very odd.
a teenage girl with rather odd hair
After a while she noticed something quite odd.
When we got inside something struck me as odd.
It's an odd little movie.
It seems odd that nobody noticed anything wrong.
It's most odd that (= very odd that) she hasn't written.
The odd thing was that he didn't recognize me.

examples.cf: it is odd to do something
examples.en: It's odd to think I will never see her again.

senses.definition: strange or unusual in the way mentioned

examples.en: an odd-looking house
an odd-sounding name

senses.definition: that cannot be divided exactly by the number two

examples.en: 1, 3, 5 and 7 are odd numbers.
Each section may have an odd or even number of players.

senses.definition: happening or appearing occasionally; not happening often

examples.en: He makes the odd mistake—nothing too serious.

senses.definition: of no particular type or size; various

examples.en: decorations made of odd scraps of paper

senses.definition: not with the pair or set that it belongs to; not matching

examples.en: You're wearing odd socks!

senses.definition: available; that somebody can use

examples.en: Could I see you when you've got an odd moment?

senses.definition: approximately or a little more than the number mentioned

examples.en: How old is she—seventy odd?
He's worked there for twenty-odd years.

senses.definition: a person or thing that is different from others or does not fit easily into a group or set

examples.en: At school he was always the odd man out.
Dog, cat, horse, shoe—which is the odd one out?

senses.definition: a person who is slightly strange or crazy
the degree to which something is likely to happen

examples.en: The odds are very much in our favour (= we are likely to succeed).
The odds are heavily against him (= he is not likely to succeed).
The odds are that (= it is likely that) she'll win.
What are the odds (= how likely is it) he won't turn up?

senses.definition: something that makes it seem impossible to do or achieve something

examples.en: They secured a victory in the face of overwhelming odds.
She defied the odds to beat the clear favourite.
to beat/overcome the odds
The film is a heart-warming tale of triumph against the odds.
Against all (the) odds, he made a full recovery.
The odds against making a profit in this business are huge.

senses.definition: the connection between two numbers that shows how much money somebody will receive if they win a bet

examples.en: odds of ten to one (= ten times the amount of money that has been bet by somebody will be paid to them if they win)
They are offering long/short odds (= the prize money will be high/low because there is a high/low risk of losing) on the defending champion.
I'll lay odds on him getting the job (= I'm sure he will get it).

senses.definition: to disagree with somebody about something

examples.en: He's always at odds with his father over politics.

senses.definition: to be different from something, when the two things should be the same

examples.en: These findings are at odds with what is going on in the rest of the country.

idioms.word: the cards/odds are stacked against you

senses.definition: you are unlikely to succeed because the conditions are not good for you

idioms.word: the cards/odds are stacked in your favour

senses.definition: you are likely to succeed because the conditions are good and you have an advantage
used to say that something is not important

examples.en: It makes no odds to me whether you go or stay.

senses.definition: more money than you would normally expect

examples.en: Many collectors are willing to pay over the odds for early examples of his work.

senses.definition: used to say that something has been removed or become separated

examples.en: He's had his beard shaved off.
Take your coat off.
The label must have fallen off.
Don't leave the toothpaste with the top off.

senses.definition: not connected or functioning

examples.en: The water is off.
Make sure the TV is off.

senses.definition: down or away from a place; at a distance in space or time

examples.en: I called him but he ran off.
I gave up riding after I fell off.
Sarah's off in India somewhere.
I must be off (= I must leave) soon.
Summer's not far off now.
A solution is still some way off.
Off you go! Enjoy yourselves!

senses.definition: away from work or duty

examples.en: She's off today.
I've got three days off next week.
How many days did you take off?
I need some time off.

senses.definition: starting a race

examples.en: They're off (= the race has begun).

senses.definition: taken from the price

examples.en: shoes with $20 off
All shirts have/are 10 per cent off.

senses.definition: no longer going to happen; cancelled

examples.en: The wedding is off.

senses.definition: no longer available or being served

examples.en: Sorry, the duck is off.

senses.definition: behind or at the sides of the stage in a theatre
to be in a better or worse situation

examples.en: She's better off without him.
The weather was so bad we'd have been better off staying at home.
We can't be any worse off than we are already.

senses.definition: to have a particular amount of something

examples.en: How are we off for coffee (= how much do we have)?

senses.definition: used to say how much money somebody has

examples.en: Families will be better off under the new law (= will have more money).
They are both comfortably off (= have enough money to be able to buy what they want without worrying too much about the cost).

senses.definition: from time to time; now and again

examples.en: It rained on and off all day.

senses.definition: down or away from a place; at a distance in space or time

examples.en: I fell off the ladder.
Keep off the grass!
an island off the coast of Spain
They were still 100 metres off the summit.
Scientists are still a long way off finding a cure.
We're getting right off the subject.

senses.definition: used to say that something has been removed

examples.en: You need to take the top off the bottle first!
I want about an inch off the back of my hair.

senses.definition: away from work or duty

examples.en: He's had ten days off school.

senses.definition: away from a price

examples.en: They knocked £500 off the car.

senses.definition: leading away from something, for example a road or room

examples.en: We live off Main Street.
There's a bathroom off the main bedroom.

senses.definition: from a person or place

examples.en: I got this off a website somewhere.

senses.definition: off; from

examples.en: She jumped off of the wall.
I got it off of my brother.

senses.definition: not wanting or liking something that you usually eat or use

examples.en: I'm off (= not drinking) alcohol for a week.
He's finally off drugs (= he no longer takes them).

senses.definition: no longer fresh enough to eat or drink

examples.en: This fish has gone off.
The milk smells off.
It's off.
I think this milk is slightly off.

senses.definition: not polite or friendly

examples.en: He was a bit off with me this morning.

senses.definition: not acceptable

examples.en: It's a bit off expecting us to work on Sunday.

senses.definition: the start of a race

examples.en: They're ready for the off.

senses.definition: to kill somebody

variants.html: (US English offense)

senses.definition: an illegal act

examples.en: a criminal/serious/minor/sexual offence
a drug/firearms/traffic offence
a first offence (= the first time that somebody has been found guilty of a crime)
a capital offence (= one for which somebody may be punished by death)
What are the alleged offences (= that have been stated but not yet proved)?
He was not aware that he had committed an offence.
New legislation makes it an offence to carry guns.
He was found guilty of offences under the Official Secrets Act.
These people have been charged with public order offences.
He has been arrested for a serious offence.
an offence against society/humanity/the state
prisoners convicted of offences against children

senses.definition: the feeling of being upset or angry at something that somebody has said or done

examples.en: The photo may cause offence to some people.
No one will take offence (= feel upset or insulted) if you leave early.
Don't be so quick to take offence.
Many readers took offence at the article.
I'm sure he meant no offence when he said that.
I didn't mean to give offence to anyone.

senses.definition: used to say that you do not mean to upset or show a lack of respect for somebody by something you say or do

examples.en: No offence, but I'd really like to be on my own.
No offence intended, but are you sure your calculations are right?

senses.definition: to make somebody feel upset because of something you say or do that is rude or embarrassing

examples.en: They'll be offended if you don't go to their wedding.
Neil did not mean to offend anybody with his joke.
She managed to offend her boyfriend’s parents as soon as she opened her mouth.
A TV interviewer must be careful not to offend.

senses.definition: to seem unpleasant to somebody

examples.en: The smell from the farm offended some people.
an ugly building that offends the eye
The show was careful not to offend local sensibilities (= hurt the feelings of local people).

senses.definition: to commit a crime or crimes

examples.en: He started offending at the age of 16.
What is the best way to stop someone who has offended from repeating the offence?

senses.definition: to be against what people believe is morally right

examples.en: comments that offend against people’s religious beliefs
Viewers complained that the broadcast offended against good taste.

senses.definition: a person who commits a crime

examples.en: a persistent/serious/violent, etc. offender
a young offender institution

senses.definition: a person or thing that does something wrong

examples.en: The report on sexual discrimination at work shows that some of the worst offenders are women.
When it comes to pollution, the chemical industry is a major offender.

senses.definition: rude in a way that causes somebody to feel upset or annoyed because it shows a lack of respect

examples.en: offensive remarks
The programme contains language which some viewers may find offensive.
racially offensive language/comments
His comments were deeply offensive to a large number of single mothers.

senses.definition: extremely unpleasant

examples.en: The problem is how to eliminate offensive smells from the processing plant.

senses.definition: connected with the act of attacking somebody/something

examples.en: an offensive war
offensive action
He was charged with carrying an offensive weapon.

senses.definition: connected with the team that has control of the ball; connected with the act of scoring points

examples.en: offensive play
an offensive player/lineman/tackle

senses.definition: a military operation in which large numbers of soldiers, etc. attack another country

examples.en: an air offensive
They launched the offensive on January 10.

senses.definition: a series of actions aimed at achieving something in a way that attracts a lot of attention

examples.en: The government has launched a new offensive against crime.
a sales offensive
The public seems unconvinced by their latest charm offensive (= their attempt to make people like them).

senses.definition: to be attacking somebody/something rather than waiting for them to attack you

examples.en: The Scots were on the offensive for most of the game.
The government is very much on the offensive in the fight against drugs.

idioms.word: go on (to) the offensive | take the offensive

senses.definition: to start attacking somebody/something before they start attacking you

examples.en: She took the offensive, challenging her critics to prove their allegations.

senses.definition: to say that you are willing to give something to somebody

examples.en: Josie had offered her services as a guide.
He offered some useful advice.
to offer support/protection/help
I don't think they need help, but I think I should offer anyway.
He offered $4 000 for the car.
They are offering a reward for the return of their cat.
They decided to offer the job to Jo.

senses.definition: used to say that you will have to wait for some time to find out the result of a situation

examples.en: Only time will tell if the treatment has been successful.

senses.definition: young people should enjoy themselves as much as possible, because they will have to work and worry later in their lives
except that; but

examples.en: I'd love to come, only I have to work.

senses.definition: used with verbs to express movement on or to a particular place or position

examples.en: Move the books onto the second shelf.

senses.definition: used to show that something faces in a particular direction

examples.en: The window looked out onto the terrace.

senses.definition: allowing things or people to go through; not closed or blocked

examples.en: A wasp flew in the open window.

The castle gates swung open.
The door burst open and the children rushed in.
She held the door open for them.
In spite of the snow, the roads remained open.
The mountain pass is kept open all year.
open borders

Taylor headed the ball into the open goal.

senses.definition: with eyelids or lips apart

examples.en: She had difficulty keeping her eyes open (= because she was very tired).

She stared at him, her mouth hanging open.

senses.definition: spread out; with the edges apart

examples.en: The flowers are all open now.
The book lay open on the table.
She put the money into his open hand.

senses.definition: not fastened or covered, so that things can easily come out or be put in

examples.en: Leave the envelope open.

I tried to pry open the locket.

senses.definition: not fastened

examples.en: Her coat was open.

senses.definition: not surrounded by anything; not closed in

examples.en: open country/countryside (= without forests, buildings, etc.)
a city with a lot of parks and wide open spaces
driving along the open road (= part of a road in the country, where you can drive fast)
We left port and headed for the open sea.

senses.definition: with no cover or roof on

examples.en: an open drain
people working in the open air (= not in a building)
The hall of the old house was open to the sky.
an open wound (= with no skin covering it)

an open flame

senses.definition: if a shop, bank, business, etc. is open, it is ready for business and will allow customers or visitors to come in

examples.en: Is the museum open on Sundays?
The new store will be open in the spring.

The bank is open for business again.

senses.definition: if a competition, meeting, etc. is open, anyone can enter, attend it, etc.

examples.en: an open debate/championship/scholarship

The debate was thrown open to the audience.

senses.definition: if a competition, building, etc. is open to particular people, those people can enter it

examples.en: The competition is open to young people under the age of 18.
The house is not open to the public.

senses.definition: to be available and ready to use

examples.en: Is the offer still open?

senses.definition: if a phone line or other channel of communication is open, it is ready to take calls, receive requests, etc.

examples.en: Lines are open 8 am to 7 pm weekdays.

senses.definition: likely to suffer something such as criticism, injury, etc.

examples.en: The system is open to abuse.

senses.definition: known to everyone; not kept hidden

their open display of affection

senses.definition: honest; not keeping thoughts and feelings hidden

examples.en: a frank and open discussion
She was always open with her parents.

senses.definition: willing to listen to and think about new ideas

examples.en: He was in an open frame of mind.
They are very open to new ideas.
I'm open to suggestions for what you would like to do in our classes.

senses.definition: not yet finally decided or settled

examples.en: The race is still wide open (= anyone could win).

senses.definition: allowing something; making something possible

examples.en: The price is not open to negotiation.
Some phrases in the contract are open to interpretation.
What she means precisely is open to debate.

senses.definition: that does not have to be used on a particular day

examples.en: I have an open ticket, so I can travel any day I like.

senses.definition: with wide spaces between the threads

examples.en: an open weave

senses.definition: produced with the tongue in the lowest possible position
if something is an open secret, many people know about it, although it is supposed to be a secret
to open suddenly or violently; to make something open in this way

examples.en: The door burst open.
Firefighters burst the door open and rescued them.

senses.definition: (to provide) the means of getting or reaching something; (to create) the opportunity for something

examples.en: The agreement will open the door to increased international trade.
Our courses are the door to success in English.

senses.definition: to be willing to listen to or accept new ideas or suggestions

examples.en: Try to keep an open mind until you've heard all the facts.

senses.definition: to listen or look out for somebody/something that you might hear or see
to look for somebody/something while you are doing other things

examples.en: Police have asked residents to keep an eye out for anything suspicious.
I walked around the store, keeping an eye out for bargains.

senses.definition: to avoid making a decision now so that you still have a choice in the future

examples.en: At the moment I'm keeping my options open and applying for as many different jobs as possible.

senses.definition: available to buy without any limits
if you describe somebody or their life as an open book, you mean that you can easily understand them and know everything about them
an invitation to somebody to visit you at any time
if something is an open invitation to criminals, etc., it encourages them to commit a crime by making it easier

examples.en: Leaving your camera on the seat in the car is an open invitation to thieves.

senses.definition: fully aware of the possible problems or results of a particular course of action

examples.en: I went into this with my eyes open so I guess I only have myself to blame.

senses.definition: if you welcome somebody with open arms, you are extremely happy and pleased to see them
to move a door, window, lid, etc. into a position that is no longer closed; to get into this position

examples.en: Mr Chen opened the car door for his wife.
She opened all the windows wide to let some fresh air in.
He opened the lid of the piano.
Do you have a key that opens this gate?
The door opened and Alan walked in.
The doors of the bus open automatically.

senses.definition: to remove or undo the top, cover, etc. of a container or package in order to see or get what is inside

examples.en: Shall I open another bottle?

She opened her bag and took out her passport.
Go on then, open the box.
I can't open this jar.

senses.definition: if you open your mouth or your mouth opens, you move your lips, for example in order to speak

examples.en: He hardly ever opens his mouth (= speaks).

senses.definition: to turn the cover or the pages of a book, newspaper, etc. so that it is no longer closed

senses.definition: to start a computer program or file so that you can use it on the screen; to become available on a computer screen

to open a file/page/window/tab

senses.definition: to spread out or unfold; to spread something out or unfold it

senses.definition: to make it possible for people, cars, goods, etc. to pass through a place

The bridge was opened to traffic in March 2017.

senses.definition: to start business for the day; to start business for the first time

examples.en: What time does the bank open?

senses.definition: to be ready for people to go to

examples.en: The new hospital opens on July 1st.

senses.definition: to start an activity or event; to begin using or doing something

examples.en: You need just one pound to open an account with us.

The police have opened an investigation into the death.

examples.en: The King officially opened the bridge in March.

senses.definition: to make it possible to reach, have, use or do something

examples.en: This decision opens the possibility of a fresh election.

senses.definition: it begins to rain heavily

examples.en: All at once the heavens opened and everyone rushed for cover.

senses.definition: to provide opportunities for somebody to do something and be successful
to realize or make somebody realize the truth about something

examples.en: Travelling really opens your eyes to other cultures.

senses.definition: to become or make somebody aware of new ideas or experiences

examples.en: He’s eager to open the minds of his audience to different kinds of music.

idioms.word: open the way for somebody/something (to do something)

senses.definition: to make it possible for somebody to do something or for something to happen

idioms.word: pour out/open your heart to somebody

senses.definition: to tell somebody all your problems, feelings, etc.

senses.definition: outdoors; the countryside

senses.definition: not hidden or secret

senses.definition: a space or hole that somebody/something can pass through

senses.definition: the beginning or first part of something

the opening of the new play

senses.definition: a good opportunity for somebody

examples.en: The skirt has a side opening.

the opening chapter of the book

to go to the opera
an opera singer
light/grand opera

senses.definition: a process in which a number or quantity is changed by adding, multiplying, etc.
connected with the way in which a business, machine, system, etc. works

examples.en: operational activities/costs/difficulties

senses.definition: ready or available to be used

senses.definition: connected with a military operation

examples.en: operational headquarters

examples.en: a computer/machine operator

senses.definition: a person or company that runs a particular business

examples.en: a tour operator
a bus operator
a train operator that runs services between London and Scotland

variants.html: (British English, old-fashioned telephonist)

senses.definition: a person who shows skill at getting what they want, especially when this involves behaving in a dishonest way

examples.en: a smooth/slick/shrewd operator

senses.definition: a symbol or function which represents an operation in mathematics
your feelings or thoughts about somebody/something, rather than a fact

examples.en: He has very strong political opinions.

to split/polarize opinion
to sway/shape/influence opinion

There is a wide body of opinion that supports this proposal.

senses.definition: your opinion that is the result of careful thought

idioms.word: have a good, bad, high, low, etc. opinion of somebody/something

senses.definition: to think that somebody/something is good, bad, etc.

senses.definition: a person that you are playing or fighting against in a game, competition, argument, etc.

opponents of the regime

a window of opportunity (= a period of time when the circumstances are right for doing something)

senses.definition: used to make a contrast between two things

senses.definition: facing the speaker or somebody/something that has been mentioned

senses.definition: as different as possible from something

senses.definition: the other sex

senses.definition: to have different aims that cannot be achieved together without causing problems

on the other side of a particular area from somebody/something, and usually facing them

senses.definition: acting in a film or play as the partner of somebody

senses.definition: on the other side of a particular area from somebody/something and usually facing them

senses.definition: the act of strongly disagreeing with somebody/something, especially with the aim of preventing something from happening

senses.definition: disagreeing strongly with somebody/something, especially with the aim of preventing something from happening

senses.definition: contrasting two people or things that are very different

optical instruments such as microscopes and telescopes

senses.definition: using light for reading or storing information

examples.en: optical storage
an optical disk/drive/mouse

senses.definition: a feeling that good things will happen and that something will be successful

senses.definition: a former British organization that worked for the rights of LGBT people. OutRage! started in 1990 and became well known for its use of direct action which it often combined with humour, as in the ‘Queer St Valentine's Day Carnival’. One of OutRage's best-known campaigners was the author and political activist Peter Tatchell. OutRage! closed down in 2011.
not in a room, building or container but on or to the outside of it

senses.definition: happening suddenly or quickly

idioms.word: have a mind of your own

senses.definition: to remain in a strong position when somebody is attacking you, competing with you, etc.

examples.en: Business isn't good but we're managing to hold our own.
She can hold her own against anybody in an argument.
The patient is holding her own although she is still very sick.

senses.definition: because of your personal qualifications or efforts, not because of your connection with somebody else

examples.en: She sings with a rock band, but she's also a jazz musician in her own right.

idioms.word: like, etc. the sound of your own voice

senses.definition: to like talking a lot or too much, usually without wanting to listen to other people

examples.en: She’s much too fond of the sound of her own voice.

senses.definition: alone; without anyone else

examples.en: I'm all on my own today.
She lives on her own.

senses.definition: without help

examples.en: He did it on his own.

senses.definition: to have something that belongs to you, especially because you have bought it

examples.en: Do you own your house or do you rent it?
I don't own anything of any value.
Most of the apartments are privately owned.
an American-owned company
Does anyone own this coat? It was left in a classroom.
Don’t tell me what to do—you don’t own me!
His father was a farmer who owned land and property.
He owns and operates an eco-tourism company.
Hospitals became publicly owned companies.

senses.definition: to manage and take responsibility for something

examples.en: The successful candidate will be responsible for owning and achieving sales targets.

senses.definition: to be completely successful, especially in a competition; to completely defeat somebody

examples.en: She owned the stage, performing a medley of hit songs.
He didn't just finish the course, he completely owned it.
Yeah right, she totally owned you, man!

senses.definition: to admit that something is true

examples.en: He owned to a feeling of guilt.
She owned (that) she had been present.

idioms.word: behave/act as if you own the place | think you own the place

senses.definition: to behave in a very confident way that annoys other people, for example by telling them what to do

examples.en: She was acting as if she owned the place.

senses.definition: a person who owns something

examples.en: a dog/pet/gun owner
a business/property/store owner
The painting has been returned to its rightful owner.
He's now the proud owner of a cottage in Wales.
Would the owner of the black Mercedes parked in front of the gates please report to reception.
They were using the land with the permission of the owner.

senses.definition: the fact of owning something

examples.en: a growth in home ownership
Ownership of the land is currently being disputed.
to be in joint/private/public ownership
The restaurant is under new ownership.

senses.definition: a chemical element. Oxygen is a gas that is present in air and water and is necessary for people, animals and plants to live.

examples.en: The patient didn't seem to be getting enough oxygen.

senses.definition: a US 24-hour digital cable and satellite television channel that started in 2000. It is aimed especially at women and since 2017 has mainly shown programmes about real-life crimes, as well as police dramas.
